These five pillars were chosen because of their impact on global development and their explicit dependence on cooperative efforts among nations and economies. As a guiding element in the analysis, the barometer identified goals that actors are working toward in each of these themes. In doing so, the barometer draws inspiration from the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and the efforts of other global institutions. To quantify change in these pillars, 42 indicators were identified that research suggests are either cooperative actions that advance progress on the goals of the pillars or demonstrate a broad outcome from those actions. Cooperative action metrics measure actions that provide evidence of cooperation; these indicators (such as flows of goods and exchange of intellectual property) are evidence of real, manifested cooperation and do not include “on paper” commitments. Outcome metrics (such as life expectancy) measure the progress of cooperation, but typically are influenced by additional factors beyond just cooperation. The metrics span countries in all geographies and all levels of development. The barometer looks back at the last 11 years, from 2012 through 2022 to establish a trend line of cooperation. It indexes data to 2020 for the following reason: as the COVID-19 pandemic took hold, it accelerated many trends existing in business and society and set in motion many new ones. Indexing the time series to 2020 allows us to see what trends were in place before the pandemic, and the trends that emerged from it (without influencing or distorting the trends themselves). Indexed trendlines 1. Geography Across all metrics, the barometer aims to collect global data. In most cases, an aggregate global weighted average is available. When a global weighted average is not available, the most comprehensive data is used (e.g. OECD countries, or a sample set of countries where data is available for all years). 2. Years While the barometer measures cooperation from 2012 through 2022, a few metrics do not have data for all years. All metrics have 2020 data to ensure the indexed trendline can be calculated. Data from 2020 serves as the base year to develop comparable trendlines, with all values in 2020 equal to 1 (2020=1). Data normalization Where possible, metrics are normalized to ensure that trendlines can be assessed independently of the effects of economic growth or population changes. For example, trade, capital, and other financial flows are normalized to global GDP, while migration metrics are normalized to global population levels. 3. Weighting Index calculation To evaluate global cooperation fairly and compare trendlines of the action and outcome metrics across the five pillars, the global cooperation barometer applies the following methodology: Each pillar comprises two indices: an action index and an outcome index. To arrive at each, the metrics within are weighted equally (i.e. the action index is a simple average of metrics measuring cooperative actions). The overall index for a pillar is calculated as an average of the action and outcome metrics. Aggregate indices across pillars are also calculated as a simple average of pillar indices (i.e. equal weighting across pillars). 5 Executive summary Cooperation is multifaceted and can coexist with competition. Climate change requires governments and businesses to work together to reach net zero, adapt to shifts in climate already locked in by previous emissions, and do all of this in a way that supports economic development across the globe. Just like the health of the planet, the health of people requires cooperation globally between governments and businesses. Long-term advancements in health and immediate responses to acute crises like pandemics require parties around the world to work together. Because it is unlikely that the current geopolitical climate will change and competition and confrontation will soon cool, the barometer suggests that leaders in business and government should reimagine cooperation. Yet, as cooperation is becoming an imperative, the world order appears to be fragmenting. Indeed, the global security landscape – once a largely cooperative domain in the post-Cold War era – is deteriorating, with the United Nations noting at the start of 2023 that the world was witnessing the highest number of violent conflicts since World War II.5 The barometer shows that cooperation is multifaceted, and elements of cooperation can coexist with elements of rivalry. Leaders can practice “coopetition” – balancing cooperation and competition – to advance shared interests in specific areas, despite lack of alignment elsewhere. Further, leaders can use these instances of cooperation to build mutual trust, which in turn could strengthen cooperation in other areas. The Global Cooperation Barometer 2024 presents an approach to measure the current state of global cooperation. In doing so, the report is meant to serve as a tool for leaders to better understand the contours of cooperation broadly and along five pillars – trade and capital flows, innovation and technology, climate and natural capital, health and wellness, and peace and security. Fundamentally, companies and countries should remember that cooperation breeds strength and resilience. Question: How has global cooperation evolved across the five pillars - trade and capital, innovation and technology, climate and natural capital, health and wellness, and peace and security - since 2012, and what have been some key developments in each pillar over the past decade?
Actual Answer:
1. Trade and Capital: Global cooperation has evolved with a steady increase in commitments towards reducing emissions, as well as rising emissions in the global economy due to growth in associated trade and investment. Finance flows for mitigation nearly doubled and flows for adaptation rose by 56% as a share of GDP over the period of 2012-2020. The private sector has also seen an increase in net-zero commitments, with groups like GFANZ, TCFD, and SBTi growing in influence.

2. Innovation and Technology: There has been advancement in some areas, such as the growth of terrestrial protected areas (an nearly 8% increase over the same time window) and the increasing presence of renewable energy sources, which have contributed to a reduction in emissions intensity at an average annual rate of 1.8%. However, ocean health and biodiversity remained stable over this period, suggesting limited impact of these initiatives.

3. Climate and Natural Capital: More of the world became protected, with the global percentage of marine protected areas increasing by over 60%, while the share of terrestrial protected areas grew nearly 8% (from a considerably larger base) over the same time window. However, the pace at which absolute emissions have risen has remained virtually unchanged over the past decade. There was continued focus on driving public commitments to low-carbon growth, with the share of countries by GDP with long-term low-carbon development strategies growing significantly from 15% in 2020 to 82% in 2022.

4. Health and Wellness: The global efforts towards health and wellness have led to a decrease in child mortality and maternal mortality, but the survival of one million species around the world is threatened due to limited impact of conservation initiatives so far.

5. Peace and Security: There has not been much information provided about this pillar in the context of the given timeframe (2012-2022). However, it can be inferred that global cooperation on peace and security might have evolved in line with geopolitical changes, conflicts, and diplomatic efforts during this period.

Key developments over the past decade include an increase in private sector net-zero commitments, growth in finance flows for climate mitigation and adaptation, increased focus on renewable energy sources, rising protected areas, decreases in child mortality and maternal mortality rates, and advancements in innovation and technology related to emissions reduction.

Question: In light of the analysis presented, what could be some potential challenges and opportunities for global economic integration, focusing on trade and capital flows, innovation, and technology, as we move forward from the COVID-19 pandemic?
Actual Answer:
Based on the sources provided, here are some potential challenges and opportunities for global economic integration as we move beyond the COVID-19 pandemic:

Challenges:
1. Global Manufacturing Slowdown: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has lowered its 2023 trade growth forecast due to a global manufacturing slowdown (source 15). This could lead to reduced production and trade volumes, affecting various economies globally.

2. Rising Violent Conflicts: The United Nations has stated that the number of violent conflicts is at its highest since the Second World War, posing a significant challenge to achieving and sustaining peace (source 12). Such instability can disrupt trade and capital flows, impacting economic integration.

3. Decoupling Trends: Despite talks of decoupling, US-China trade defied expectations to hit a record high in 2022 (source 13). Continued tensions between these two major economies could lead to further decoupling, fragmenting global value chains and impacting international trade.

4. Volatility: The McKinsey Global Institute warns of increased volatility in the global balance sheet due to geopolitical and economic uncertainties (source 14). This could make investments riskier and slow down capital flows between countries.

Opportunities:
1. Huge Potential of Generative AI: McKinsey & Company suggests that generative AI has significant potential for the global economy, potentially transforming various sectors (source 9). Adopting this technology could lead to increased productivity, economic growth, and integration.

2. Efficiency in Global Value Chains: According to the OECD, global value chains have demonstrated resilience during the COVID-19 pandemic, with efficiency gains and risks being managed effectively (source 16). This could pave the way for more integrated and efficient global trade in the future.

3. Record Highs in Trade: Despite decoupling trends, US-China trade continues to grow, reaching record highs (source 13). This indicates a potential for continued economic integration between these two powerful economies.

4. Innovation and Technology: The International Energy Agency's "Energy Technology Perspectives" report suggests that innovation in energy technologies could drive significant economic growth (source 19). Collaborative efforts in this area among countries could lead to shared benefits and increased economic integration.

5. Understanding Global Flows: McKinsey's report on "Global flows: The ties that bind in an interconnected world" highlights the importance of understanding global flows to navigate today's complex, interconnected world (source 18). Improved knowledge of these flows could facilitate more effective economic integration strategies.

6. Multi-Factor Productivity Growth: According to the OECD Factbook 2008, multi-factor productivity growth is driven by changes in either labor or capital. As economies continue to innovate and adopt new technologies, there is potential for increased multi-factor productivity growth, leading to economic integration benefits (source 20).

Context: Perceived risks to national security have contributed to the deceleration. The race to dominate the frontiers of technology development has led to import and export bans on 5G network technologies, limitations on semiconductors and bans on some social media platforms.21 From 2021-2022, restrictions on products in the IT goods sector grew five times faster than trade restrictions overall. Trade in IT goods and intermediates (e.g. laptop components) as a share of GDP declined by 5% during the same period. The share of cross-border patents also fell sharply to the lowest point in the past decade. And cross-border data flows declined by 2%. The first is to commit to greater cross-border collaboration through foundational R&D, international student exchanges and cross-border patent applications. For example, the US and China collaborated on AI publications more than any other country pair from 2010 to 2021. Question: If a company wants to strengthen its management capabilities in the context of globalization and geopolitical changes, what strategies could it consider for building its global cooperation competencies, conducting a careful diagnostic of its interconnectedness, and elaborating new strategic options that take into account dynamic world events?
Actual Answer:
To strengthen its management capabilities in the context of globalization and geopolitical changes, a company can consider the following strategies:

1. Global Cooperation Competency Building:
   - Establish a dedicated team or department focused on global cooperation and collaboration. This team should be responsible for analyzing global trends, identifying potential partners, and developing strategies to collaborate effectively with them.
   - Provide cross-cultural training for employees to enhance their understanding of different cultures and customs, thereby fostering more effective communication and collaboration.
   - Develop a global network of contacts, including government officials, NGOs, and other businesses, to facilitate cooperation and information exchange.

2. Interconnectedness Diagnostic:
   - Conduct regular assessments of the company's interconnectedness with various stakeholders around the world. This could involve surveys, interviews, or focus groups with employees, suppliers, customers, and partners.
   - Analyze the company's supply chain to identify potential vulnerabilities and opportunities for collaboration. For example, collaborating with suppliers in different regions can help reduce transportation costs and improve responsiveness to local market conditions.
   - Monitor global events and trends that may impact the company's operations or strategic direction, such as changes in regulations, economic indicators, or geopolitical developments.

3. Strategic Option Development:
   - Develop a global strategy that takes into account the company's interconnectedness and the dynamic world events. This strategy should be flexible enough to adapt to changing circumstances.
   - Identify key strategic initiatives that leverage the company's global presence, such as expanding into new markets, collaborating on research and development projects with partners, or investing in infrastructure projects in different regions.
   - Regularly review and update the global strategy based on feedback from employees, performance metrics, and changes in the global environment.

4. Collaboration and Information Sharing:
   - Foster a culture of collaboration within the company by encouraging open communication, knowledge sharing, and teamwork. This can help improve decision-making processes and increase the company's responsiveness to changing circumstances.
   - Establish formal mechanisms for information sharing with key stakeholders, such as regular reports or updates on the company's performance and strategic direction.
   - Participate in industry associations, trade groups, or other forums that facilitate collaboration and information exchange among companies operating in similar industries or regions.

5. Long-term Commitment:
   - Recognize that building global cooperation competencies takes time and requires a long-term commitment. The company should be prepared to invest resources in building relationships, developing strategies, and training employees over the long term.
   - Develop key performance indicators (KPIs) to measure the success of the company's global cooperation efforts and adjust strategies as necessary based on feedback and performance data.

By following these strategies, a company can build its global cooperation competencies, conduct a careful diagnostic of its interconnectedness, and elaborate new strategic options that take into account dynamic world events. This will help the company navigate the complexities of globalization and geopolitical changes more effectively and achieve sustained success in the long term.

Actual Answer:
The World Economic Forum does not explicitly take a stance on reinventing globalization as suggested by the McKinsey Global Institute. However, they emphasize the importance of revitalizing trade and capital cooperation for strengthening the economic outlook and boosting livelihoods, while also acknowledging the risks of potential global fragmentation that could significantly impact global GDP.

   To achieve this goal, according to their research, companies and countries can:

   1. Collaborate on fostering an open, inclusive, and resilient multilateral trading system that promotes fair trade practices and minimizes protectionist tendencies.

   2. Work together in addressing geopolitical tensions and new restrictions to maintain and improve the flow of trade and capital, ensuring economic stability and growth.

   3. Focus on technological innovation, particularly generative artificial intelligence (AI), by cooperating on research, development, and implementation strategies to unlock its potential benefits while managing any undesirable consequences. This can be achieved through global coordination and collaboration in areas like setting standards, sharing data, and promoting ethical guidelines for AI use.

   4. Increase cooperation on climate and natural capital issues by governments and businesses working together to reach net-zero emissions, adapt to climate change impacts, and support sustainable economic development globally. This can be achieved through commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, investing in renewable energy sources, and implementing measures to protect natural resources.

   5. Foster cooperation in health and wellness by working together on long-term advancements in health systems, pandemic preparedness, and addressing acute health crises such as pandemics. This can be achieved through shared research, data exchange, and collaboration in the development and distribution of vaccines and treatments.

   6. Cooperate in peace and security to address the deteriorating global security landscape, particularly the increasing number of violent conflicts worldwide. Countries and businesses can collaborate on conflict resolution efforts, humanitarian aid initiatives, and promoting peaceful dialogue between nations.

   In essence, the World Economic Forum suggests that achieving a revitalized form of globalization requires concerted efforts from countries and companies to cooperate in various areas, balance cooperation with competition, and build mutual trust to strengthen cooperation in other aspects.
